title: Alternative splicing of DSP1 enhances snRNA accumulation by promoting transcription termination and recycle of the processing complex
abstract: Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) are the basal components of the spliceosome and play crucial roles in splicing. Their biogenesis is spatiotemporally regulated. However, related mechanisms are still poorly understood. Defective in snRNA processing (DSP1) is an essential component of the DSP1 complex that catalyzes plant snRNA 3'-end maturation by cotranscriptional endonucleolytic cleavage of the primary snRNA transcripts (presnRNAs). Here, we show that DSP1 is subjected to alternative splicing in pollens and embryos, resulting in two splicing variants, DSP1α and DSP1β. Unlike DSP1α, DSP1β is not required for presnRNA 3'-end cleavage. Rather, it competes with DSP1α for the interaction with CPSF73-I, the catalytic subunit of the DSP1 complex, which promotes efficient release of CPSF73-I and the DNA-dependent RNA polymerease II (Pol II) from the 3' end of snRNA loci thereby facilitates snRNA transcription termination, resulting in increased snRNA levels in pollens. Taken together, this study uncovers a mechanism that spatially regulates snRNA accumulation.

body:
SignificancesnRNAs are conserved noncoding RNAs in eukaryotes. Their biogenesis is spatiotemporally regulated in various biological processes. However, related mechanisms regulating snRNA accumulation are less known. DSP1 is an essential component of the DSP1 complex that catalyzes snRNA maturation. Here, we show that DSP1 is subjected to alternative splicing in the pollens, resulting in two splicing variants, DSP1α and DSP1β. DSP1β does not participate in the 3′ maturation of snRNAs but interacts with CPSF73-I and promotes efficient release of CPSF73-I and Poll II from the 3′ end of the snRNA loci and thereby facilitates snRNA transcription termination, resulting in increased snRNA levels in pollens. Our results uncover a mechanism spatiotemporally regulating snRNA biogenesis in plants.Keywords: snRNA, transcript termination, DSP1, alternative splicing, DSP1α AbstractSmall nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) are the basal components of the spliceosome and play crucial roles in splicing. Their biogenesis is spatiotemporally regulated. However, related mechanisms are still poorly understood. Defective in snRNA processing (DSP1) is an essential component of the DSP1 complex that catalyzes plant snRNA 3′-end maturation by cotranscriptional endonucleolytic cleavage of the primary snRNA transcripts (presnRNAs). Here, we show that DSP1 is subjected to alternative splicing in pollens and embryos, resulting in two splicing variants, DSP1α and DSP1β. Unlike DSP1α, DSP1β is not required for presnRNA 3′-end cleavage. Rather, it competes with DSP1α for the interaction with CPSF73-I, the catalytic subunit of the DSP1 complex, which promotes efficient release of CPSF73-I and the DNA-dependent RNA polymerease II (Pol II) from the 3′ end of snRNA loci thereby facilitates snRNA transcription termination, resulting in increased snRNA levels in pollens. Taken together, this study uncovers a mechanism that spatially regulates snRNA accumulation. snRNAs are basal components of the spliceosome and play essential roles in the splicing of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) (1, 2). Most snRNAs (U1, U2, U4, and U5) are transcribed as presnRNAs by the DNA-dependent RNA Pol II. PresnRNAs are subjected to 3′ maturation, which removes the RNA fragment transcribed beyond the 3′ end of mature snRNAs by cotranscriptional endonucleolytic cleavage followed by a cytoplasmic 3′-to-5′ exonucleolytic trimming step (3, 4). The endonucleolytic cleavage occurs at the upstream of an RNA motif called the 3′ box and is catalyzed by the DSP1 complex and the integrator complex (INT) in plants and metazoans, respectively (5–9).The DSP1 complex contains, at least, five components: DSP1–DSP4 and the cleavage and polyadenylation specificity factor of 73 kDa I (CPSF73-I). CPSF73-I is a metallo-β-lactamase/β-CASP family RNA endonuclease, which also cleaves the 3′ end of premRNAs. DSP1 acts as a scaffold to bridge CPSF73-I and its catalytically inactive homolog DSP4. DSP1 and DSP4 are both required for the efficient and accurate cleavage of presnRNAs (8, 10). INT is composed of, at least, 14 subunits, including INT9, a paralog of CPSF73-I and its homolog INT11, a counterpart of DSP4. INT9 and INT11 form a catalytic active heterodimer and cleave presnRNAs (9, 11). INT also promotes the transcription termination of snRNAs, histone mRNAs, and some poly-A mRNAs (12). If not properly terminated, the 3′-read-through transcripts of presnRNAs can be produced, resulting in extended chimeric RNAs named “snmRNAs,” which contain protein-coding sequences of downstream of snRNA loci in metazoans (13–15). Besides snRNA maturation, the DSP1 complex and INT play essential roles in development since their mutants display various developmental defects and/or embryo lethality (8, 16–19). For instance, the weak dsp1-1 mutation results in smaller plant size and defects in pollen and embryo development (8).Important structural and functional roles of snRNAs in the spliceosome suggest that they may be present in cells at constant amounts (20–22). However, snRNA levels vary among different organs and developmental stages (2, 23, 24), and the spatiotemporal regulation of snRNA accumulation is critical for various biological processes (25–27). For example, the snRNA contents are correlated with the amount of the transcription activator SHOOT REDIFFERENTIATION DEFECTIVE 2 (SRD2), which is strongly expressed in highly proliferated tissues, and impaired function of SRD2 has a stronger impact on the development of these tissues (24). Various conserved transcription factors that control snRNA transcription have been identified in plants and metazoans (21, 28, 29). However, the mechanism regulating the spatiotemporal accumulation of snRNAs is still less known.Alternative splicing (AS) is a conserved posttranscriptional mechanism that generates multiple mRNAs from a coding gene through the selection of variable splicing sites, diversifying genetic information for limited gene numbers (30–34). AS also influences gene expression levels as transcripts generated by AS are often degraded through nonsense mediated decay (NMD) (35, 36). Several features of AS transcripts trigger a translation-dependent NMD pathway, including premature termination codons (PTCs), long 3′-UTR, downstream splice junction, and upstream open reading frames (ORFs) (37). However, some AS transcripts can generate truncated proteins with altered function, stability, and/or cellular localization (30–34). In plants, AS affects multiple important biological processes, including development, circadian rhythm, starch metabolism, hormone signaling, flowering time, and responses to biotic and abiotic stresses (38–44). More than 60% of Arabidopsis and 40% of Brachypodium distachyon genes are subjected to AS (37, 42). Yet, the biological consequences of most AS events remain unexplored.Here, we show that an AS form of DSP1 (DSP1β) is essential for snRNA biogenesis and for the development of pollens and embryos. DSP1β is specifically expressed in pollens and embryos, suggesting that it is an organ- or developmental stage-specific regulator. DSP1β and the original DSP1 form (DSP1α) act cooperatively since each of them alone is necessary but not sufficient to maintain snRNA biogenesis and pollen/embryo development. DSP1β only contains the first Armadillo/β-cateninlike (ARM) cluster of the three existing in DSP1α, through which both variants interact with CPSF73-I. We show that DSP1β reduces the DSP1α-CPSF73-I interaction by direct competition and thereby promotes the release of CPSF73-I and Pol II from the 3′ end of snRNA genes, preventing the production of 3′-read-through transcripts of presnRNAs. We propose that DSP1β enhances snRNA biogenesis through facilitating the transcription termination of snRNAs and the rapid cycle of CPSF73-I in pollens. ResultsPollen and Embryo Developments Require Two Splicing Variants of DSP1. As previously reported (8), the hypomorphic dsp1-1 mutant in which the expression levels of DSP1 are reduced by a T-DNA inserted in the second intron (8) had pleiotropic developmental defects, including a reduction in plant size, fertility, and pollen viability, compared with Columbia (Col) (wild-type, [WT]) (SI Appendix, Fig. S1 A–C). Expression of a WT copy of the DSP1 gene driven by its native promoter (pDSP1::GDSP1-MYC) rescued the developmental defects of dsp1-1 (SI Appendix, Fig. S1). Interestingly, the expression of the DSP1-coding sequence (pDSP1::DSP1-MYC) rescued the vegetative phenotypes in the 24 transgenic lines tested, but not the pollen and seed development defects in T2 plants (SI Appendix, Fig. S1 A–C). The levels of DSP1-MYC were similar in transgenic dsp1-1 harboring pDSP1::GDSP1-MYC or pDSP1:DSP1-MYC (SI Appendix, Fig. S1D). These results led us to hypothesize that normal pollen and embryo developments might require an AS variant generated by DSP1. To identify the splice variants, we performed RT-PCR analysis on RNAs from flowers and seeds using a series of primer pairs (P1–P5) recognizing various positions of the DSP1 gene (Fig. 1A, p1–p5). Both p2 and p3 detected potential DSP1 splicing variants (Fig. 1B). Because the fragments amplified by p2 and p3 overlap in exon 3 and exon 4, this result suggests that an alternative splicing form of DSP1 may exist. This variant was named as DSP1β while the original DSP1 transcript was renamed as DSP1α. Sequencing analysis showed that an alternative 5′-splicing site in the third exon of DSP1 was used to generate DSP1β in which a 3′ portion of the third exon (nucleotides: 1,175–1,242 in the genomic DNAs) was removed compared with DSP1α (Fig. 1A–C and SI Appendix, Fig. S2 A–C) and results in a PTC in the fourth exon. Because PTC may trigger the RNA NMD), we asked if DSP1β is a target of NMD. We compared the accumulation of DSP1β in Col with that in iba1 (AT5G47010), which is defective in the NMD pathway (45). The NMD-sensitive AS transcript of MADS AFFECTING FLOWERING 3 (MAF3, At5g65060) (37) was used as the control. iba1 increased the levels of the MAF3-AS transcript but not the DSP1β transcript (SI Appendix, Fig. S2D), suggesting that DSP1β may not be a target of NMD. To determine if DSP1β could produce a functional protein, we used the coding region of DSP1β to generate a chimeric construct driven by a 35S promoter with a hemagglutinin (HA) tag at the N terminus and a green fluorescent protein (GFP) tag at the C terminus (p35S::HA-DSP1β-GFP) according to Ghelli et al. (44) (Fig. 1D). When transiently expressed in Nicotiana benthamiana (N. benthamiana), the transgene produced an ∼63 Kd protein, which is the predicted size for HA-DSP1β-GFP, resulting in a GFP signal (Fig. 1D). To confirm that DSP1β was, indeed, translated in vivo, we generated an antibody recognizing both DSP1α and DSP1β (SI Appendix, Fig. S2G). This antibody detected the existence of DSP1β in flower but not in seedlings (SI Appendix, Fig. S2E). Moreover, we found that the levels of DSP1α and DSP1β were reduced in the weak dsp1-1 allele (8). These results demonstrate that DSP1β was, indeed, translated into a protein in vivo.Open in a separate windowFig. 1.Both DSP1α and DSP1β are required for pollen and embryo developments. (A) Diagram of the DSP1 gene structure and primer positions used for the identification of alternative splicing variants. Gray box: exons; solid black line: intron; arrowheads: primers used for RT-PCR; P1 ∼ P5: the PCR fragments amplified with corresponding primer pairs. (B) RT-PCR analysis of DSP1 splicing patterns between the different exons. Arrows indicate the AS form. F: flowers; S: seeds. (C) Diagram of cDNAs of DSP1α and DSP1β. The splicing sites and the premature stop codon are shown. (D) Transient expression of the HA-DSP1β-GFP transgene (Top) in N. benthamiana. (Left) Confocal microscopy image shown the GFP signal (green) from fusion protein and plant autoflorencence (red), and white arrows indicate the GFP signal areas. (Scale bar = 10 μm.) (Right) Western blot for the HA tag, channel 1: WT; channel 2: HA-DSP1β-GFP; channel 3: HA-GST. (E) Analysis of pollen viability by scanning electron microscope (Top, scale bar = 10 μm), Alexander staining (Middle, scale bar = 10 μm), and transmission electron microscope ([TEM], Bottom, scale bar = 1 μm.) (F) Developing seeds in dissected green siliques. (Scale bar = 1 mm.)Next, we asked if DSP1β and DSP1α are required for pollen and embryo developments. Expression of DSP1α (pDSP1::DSP1α-MYC) in dsp1-1 alone recovered the defects of seedlings, but not pollen and seeds, while expression of DSP1β (pDSP1::DSP1β-MYC) alone failed to rescue all of the developmental defects of dsp1-1 (Figs. 1 E and F and SI Appendix, Fig. S2F). However, pollen and embryo defects were completely rescued when both DSP1β and DSP1α were introduced into dsp1-1 (Fig. 1 E and F). These results demonstrate that DSP1β and DSP1α are both required for pollen and seed development and that DSP1α but not DSP1β is required for seedling development.DSP1β Is Specifically Expressed in Pollen and Embryos. To understand how DSP1β and DSP1α act coordinately in Arabidopsis, we first evaluated their expression in various organs of WT. A semiquantitative RT-PCR analysis showed that DSP1α was expressed in all selected tissues, while DSP1β was only detectable in flowers and developing seeds (Fig. 2A). To further examine their expression patterns, we generated stable β-glucuronidase (GUS) reporters fused with the genomic DNA of DSP1α or DSP1β driven by the native DSP1 promoter (pDSP1::GDSP1[α or β]-GUS) (Fig. 2D). pDSP1::GDSP1β-GUS could generate two transcripts, DSP1β-GUS or DSP1α (truncated)-GUS due to alternative splicing. However, DSP1α (truncated)-GUS could not be translated into a functional GUS protein because it contains a reading frameshift at the start codon of GUS (SI Appendix, Fig. S2H). Thus, the GUS levels should reflect DSP1β protein levels in the transgenic plants containing pDSP1::GDSP1β-GUS. DSP1β was detected in pollen, the pollinated embryo sac, the radicle zone of the fully developed embryo, and in the young cotyledon (Fig. 2 C and D), while DSP1α-GUS was present in the whole seedling and embryo of transgenic plants. Interestingly, both DSP1β and DSP1α were absent from the ovules (Fig. 2C). These results agree with the essential role of DSP1β in pollen and seed development and the critical functions of DSP1α in various tissues except for female organs (8).Open in a separate windowFig. 2.Expression patterns of DSP1α and DSP1β. (A) Expression of DSP1α and DSP1β in various tissues. UBQ was used as an amplification control. (B) Diagram of the DSP1α- and DSP1β-GUS reporter constructs. The transgenes were driven by the native DSP1 promoter. The DSP1β premature stop codon at 1519 was removed. Gray box: exons; black line: intron; black box: alternative splicing region. (C and D) Representative images of GUS staining in various tissues of plants harboring pDSP1::GDSP1α-GUS (Bottom) and GDSP1β-GUS (Top). The black or white arrowheads indicate the DSP1β-GUS signal areas. DAE: days after emasculation; DAP: days after pollination.DSP1 Splicing Variant Exists in Eudicots. Because of its importance, we asked if DSP1β is also present in additional eudicot plants, such as Camelina sativa, Brassica rapa, Glycine max, Cucumis sativus, and Nicotiana sylvestris, or monocot plants, such as Zea mays and Oryza sativa. Interestingly, we observed similar DSP1 third exon splicing variants by RT-PCR and sequencing in all examined eudicot plants but not in the monocot plants (SI Appendix, Fig. S3 and Table S1). Hence, this splicing pattern we observed here may be evolutionarily conserved among Eudicots.DSP1α and DSP1β Are Both Required for snRNA Biogenesis in Pollen. Next, we asked if both DSP1α and DSP1β are required for snRNA biogenesis. We examined the accumulation of snRNAs and presnRNAs in the pollens of WT, dsp1-1, and dsp1-1 harboring DSP1α, DSP1β, or DSP1α +DSP1β. The expression of DSP1α reduced the accumulation of presnRNAs and did not affect the accumulation snRNAs, while the expression of DSP1β recovered snRNA levels accompanied with increased levels of presnRNAs (Fig. 3 A–C). In addition, coexpression of DSP1α and DSP1β recovered the accumulation of both presnRNAs and snRNAs (Fig. 3 A–C). These results demonstrate that proper snRNA biogenesis in pollen requires both DSP1β and DSP1α.Open in a separate windowFig. 3.Both DSP1α and DSP1β are required for snRNA biosynthesis in pollens. (A and B) Accumulation of mature snRNAs detected by qRT-PCR (A) or Northern blot (B). (C) Accumulation of presnRNAs detected by qRT-PCR. PresnRNA and mature snRNA levels were normalized to ACT2 and compared with Col in qRT-PCR. Values are means of three biological replicates. Error bars indicate SD. *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01 (Student’s t test). U6 was used as a loading control for Northern blot. (D) In vitro pre-U2.3-polyG 3′-end processing by nuclear protein extracts. The black arrow indicates the input. The gray arrow indicates the mature snRNAs. The relative processing efficiency was shown under the band of mature U2.3 snRNA. The radioactive signals of mature U2.3 RNAs of various genotypes were normalized to the input and compared with those of Col to obtain relative processing efficiency of various genotypes, and the value of Col was set to 1.Next, we asked the function of DSP1β and DSP1α in snRNA 3′ maturation using an in vitro processing assay (8). In this assay, an in vitro transcribed [32P] pre-U2.3-polyG RNA in which the poly-G was added to prevent 3′ trimming was processed in protein extracts from anthers of various genotypes. The result showed that DSP1α but not DSP1β recovered the presnRNA cleavage efficiency in dsp1-1 (Fig. 3D), revealing that DSP1α is required for efficient presnRNA 3′ cleavage while DSP1β likely has roles other than 3′-end cleavage of presnRNAs.We also asked the role of DSP1α and DSP1β in snRNA biogenesis in seedlings. In seedlings, DSP1α but not DSP1β rescued the presnRNA accumulation in dsp1-1 in which presnRNA abundance is elevated due to impaired snRNA 3′ cleavage, and snRNAs levels were not changed (SI Appendix, Fig. S4 A–C). Moreover, overexpression of DSP1β in seedlings of WT did not affect the accumulation of both presnRNAs and snRNAs (SI Appendix, Fig. S4 D and E) (8). These results together with the pollen specific expression of DSP1β suggest that DSP1β likely promotes snRNA accumulation in pollen. Indeed, we observed a higher accumulation of mature snRNAs in pollen relative to seedlings (SI Appendix, Fig. S4F). We also examined the impact of DSP1β on the 3′ processing of FCA. Like DSP1α, DSP1β does not affect 3′-end processing of premRNAs (SI Appendix, Fig. S4G).We further asked if DSP1 affects snRNA accumulation through modulating the stability of presnRNAs. We measured presnRNA half-lives after treating plants with cordycepin, an inhibitor of transcription. However, we did not observe obvious differences of presnRNA half-lives among Col, dsp1-1, dsp1-1+ DSP1α, and dsp1-1+ DSP1β (SI Appendix, Fig. S4H).DSP1α and DSP1β Compete for the Interaction with CSPF73-I. We sought to determine how DSP1β acts in snRNA biogenesis. DSP1β contains the first cluster of the ARM repeats (∼40 aa for each repeat) of DSP1α (Fig. 4A) and localized in the nucleus (Fig. 4B). Since ARM repeats are known to mediate protein–protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions, we suspected that DSP1β might compete with DSP1α for its interaction partners (DNAs or proteins). We first asked if, like DSP1α, DSP1β binds the snRNA loci. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assay showed that DSP1β did not bind the U1a and U2.3 snRNA loci (SI Appendix, Fig. S5 A and B), indicating that DSP1β may not compete with DSP1α for DNA binding.Open in a separate windowFig. 4.DSP1α and DSP1β interact with CPSF73-I through the first ARM domain. (A) Diagrams of the DSP1α and DSP1β protein structures. The green boxes indicate ARM domains in DSP1 protein. (B) DSP1β-GFP signal observed in the nucleus of transiently transformed N. benthamiana cells. (C and D) BiFC (C) and co-IP (D) analyses of the interaction between DSP1β and CPSF73-I. OE: Overexpression line. CPSF73-I was detected with antibodies recognizing CPSF73-I. (E) Diagram of full-length and truncated DSP1α and CPSF73-I proteins. (F and G) BiFC (F) and co-IP (G) analyses of the DSP1α∆ARM1-CPSF73-I interaction. CPSF73-I was detected with antibodies recognizing CPSF73-I. (H and I) BiFC (H) and co-IP (I) analyses of DSP1β-CPSF73-I-Trs interactions. BiFC was performed in tobacco epidermal cells or protoplasts (C). Co-IP assays were performed using anti-MYC for IP.Next, we asked if DSP1β could compete with DSP1α for protein interaction. We first examined the interaction of DSP1β with the DSP1α-interacting partners, Pol II, CPSF73-I, and DSP4. DSP1β did not interact with Pol II and DSP4 in bimolecular fluorescence complementation (BiFC) and co-IP assays. It also did not interact with DSP2 or DSP3 (SI Appendix, Fig. S5 C and D). However, it did interact with CPSF73-I in both BiFC (Fig. 4C) and co-IP (Fig. 4D). These results suggested that the first ARM domain of DSP1α was responsible for DSP1-CPSF73-I interactions. Indeed, when the first ARM domain was removed (DSP1α∆ARM1) (Fig. 4E), DSP1α failed to interact with CPSF73-I (Fig. 4 F and G). Next, we investigated the CPSF73-I protein domain responsible for DSP1 interactions. We tested three truncated versions of CPSF73-I: Tr1, Tr2, and Tr3, which contained only the lactamase, β-Casp, and C-terminal domains, respectively (Fig. 4E). Of the three truncated proteins, only Tr2 interacted with DSP1β in BiFC and co-IP assays (Fig. 4 H and I). This indicated that the β-Casp domain is solely responsible for mediating the interaction between the CPSF73-I and the DSP1 variants.We further analyzed the effect of DSP1β on the DSP1α-CPSF73-I interaction. Co-IP assays showed that the DSP1α-CPSF73-I interaction was dramatically reduced in the presence of DSP1β, while the DSP1α-DSP4 interaction was not affected (Fig. 5A). To qualitatively and quantitatively analyze the effect of DSP1β on DSP1α-CPSF73-I interaction in vivo, we performed a fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) assay. Because the fluorescence signals from full-length DSP1α-cyan fluorescent (CFPs) or CPSF73-I-yellow fluorescent proteins (YFPs) were weak and easily quenched, we used truncated proteins containing the protein-interaction domains for this assay. We cotransfected truncated DSP1α (aa 1–504) and CPSF73-I (aa 1–473), tagged with CFP and YFP, respectively, into N. benthamiana cells. FRET confirmed that the interaction between DSP1α and CPSF73-I was greatly reduced when DSP1β was present (Fig. 5B). DSP3, which interacts with CPSF73-I (8), was also coexpressed in the FRET experiments as a control. DSP3 slightly enhanced the DSP1α-CPSF73-I interaction, confirming the specificity of the competition between the AS variants.Open in a separate windowFig. 5.DSP1β competes with DSP1α for the interaction with CSPF73-I. (A) CoIP of DSP1α with CPSF73-I or DSP4 in the presence or absence of DSP1β. IP was performed using the anti-MYC antibody. The red rectangle shows the interaction impaired by DSP1β. (B) FRET images of CFP, YFP, and FRET channels collected from DSP1α-YFP/CPSF73-I-CFP cotransfected N. benthamiana cells. FRET intensity gradient is indicated in the FRET channel image. Mean normalized FRET values (NFRET) were calculated from six separate FRET images. Error bars represent the SD. *P < 0.05 (Student’s t test).DSP1β Affects CPSF73-I/Pol II Occupancy at the Downstream of the snRNA Loci. The competition between DSP1 variants raised the possibility that DSP1β may affect CPSF73-I activity. However, coexpression of DSP1α and DSP1β did not affect presnRNA 3′-end processing in vitro (Fig. 3D). Thus, we suspected that the competition between DSP1β and DSP1α might help the recycle CPSF73-I during snRNA 3′ maturation, which occurs cotranscriptionally. In this scenario, the release of CPSF73-I from the snRNA loci should be affected by DSP1β in pollen. We used microChIP to analyze the occupancy of CPSF73-I at snRNA loci. CPSF73-I occupancy at the promoter, coding, and 3′-box regions of the snRNA loci was reduced in dsp1-1 relative to WT. Conversely, CPSF73-I occupancy increased at the 3′-downstream (DS) region of snRNA loci (Fig. 6 A and B). Expression of DSP1α partially recovered CPSF73-I occupancy at the promoter, coding, and 3′ box but not at the DS region. Interestingly, DSP1β completely recovered CPSF73-I occupancy at the DS region but had no or weak effects elsewhere (Fig. 6 A and B). Coexpression of DSP1α and DSP1β completely recovered CPSF73-I occupancy at all tested regions of the snRNA loci (Fig. 6 A and B). We also analyzed the impact of DSP1β and DSP1α on Pol II occupancy at various regions of snRNA loci in pollen. The results mimicked the observation for CPSF73-I (Fig. 6 C and D). These results suggest that DSP1β is required for the release of CPSF73-I and Pol II at the DS region of snRNA loci. In contrast with the observation in pollens, DSP1β had no impact on CPSF73-I or Pol II occupancy at snRNA loci in seedlings (SI Appendix, Fig. S6), further confirming that DSP1β acts specifically in pollen.Open in a separate windowFig. 6.DSP1β reduces the occupancy of CPSF73-I and Pol II at the 3′-downstream regions of the snRNA loci. (A–D) Occupancy of CPSF73-I (A and B) or Pol II (C and D) at various sites of the U2.3 (A and C) or U1a (B and D) snRNA loci detected by microChIP. Pro: promoter; DS region of snRNAs. Values are means of three technical replicates. Error bars indicate SD. *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01 (Student’s t test compared with dsp1-1 samples).DSP1β Is Required for Transcription Termination of snRNAs. The effect of DSP1 variants on Pol II/CPSF73-I release from snRNA loci suggests that DSP1β but not DSP1α plays a positive role in snRNA transcription termination in pollen. We used a nuclear run on (NRO) assay to test this possibility. In this assay, we used U2.3 as a reporter. After NRO, the levels of snRNA transcripts were evaluated using probes targeting the coding/mature snRNAs (P1), 3′-box (P2), and 3′-downstream regions (P3 and P4 indicate read-through transcripts, Fig. 7A). Relative to WT, the levels of de novo read-through transcripts, which are transcribed far beyond the normal termination site for presnRNAs (SI Appendix, Fig. S7 and Dataset S1), were increased in dsp1-1 and dsp1-1+DSP1α but not in dsp1-1+DSP1β (Fig. 7A). This indicates that DSP1β but not DSP1α promotes the termination of snRNA transcription. To further validate these results, we used a pre-U2m-GUS reporter where a mutation in the 3′ box prevents cleavage at the 3′ end, resulting in the accumulation of a read-through transcript, which can be translated into a functional GUS protein (8). GUS levels depend on the amount of read-through transcripts of pre-U2m-GUS. We detected a weak GUS signal in WT pollen where DSP1β is expressed, suggesting that transcription is terminated efficiently at the 3′ box of the reporter (Fig. 7 B and C). Read-through transcript levels were increased in dsp1-1 relative to WT (Fig. 7 B and C). Expression of DSP1β but not DSP1α recovered the transcript termination defect (Fig. 7B). DiscussionAlternative splicing utilizes alternative splice sites to generate multiple mRNAs from a single genetic locus, increasing the biological diversity obtained from a limited number of genes (30–34). In plants, limited alternative splicing events have been studied in detail, partially due to that most splicing variants are degraded (30–32, 34, 35). In this study, we show DSP1β, a splicing variant of DSP1, is required for plant development and snRNA biogenesis. Despite that DSP1β harbors a PTC, a signal triggering RNA degradation, it is translated into a truncated DSP1 protein. Intriguingly, DSP1β promotes snRNA biogenesis through competing with DSP1α, the full-length DSP1 protein, for the interaction with CPSF73-I.The snRNA biogenesis defection in dsp1-1 cannot be recovered by either DSP1α or DSP1β alone, indicating the snRNA biogenesis requires the coordinated action of both variants. DSP1α and DSP1β act differently in snRNA biogenesis. DSP1α functions as a component of the DSP1 complex to facilitate snRNA 3′-end maturation (Fig. 3D), but DSP1β is not required for presnRNA 3′ cleavage. Instead, it seems to be a rate-determining factor for the accumulation of mature snRNAs in pollen, given the fact that the expression of DSP1β but not DSP1α is sufficient to recover the accumulation of mature snRNAs in the hypomorphic dsp1-1 mutant in which low levels of both variants can be generated. DSP1β contains only the first ARM cluster of the DSP1α protein. Unlike DSP1α, DSP1β does not interact with Pol II, DSP4, or snRNA loci but interacts with CPSF73-I. When both variants are present, the DSP1α-CPSF73-I interaction is reduced, indicating that DSP1β competes with DSP1α for CPSF73-I (Fig. 8). When DSP1β is lacking, the occupancy of both CPSF73-I and Pol II at the downstream of the 3′ box of snRNA loci increased, and read-through transcripts from snRNA loci accumulated, despite the presence of DSP1α, suggesting a defection in transcription termination. These results reveal that the interaction of DSP1β with CPSF73-I likely facilitates the release of CPSF73-I and Pol II after or during snRNA 3′-end processing, which occurs cotranscriptionally. Hence, DSP1β promotes the rapid recycle of the DSP1 complex and Pol II and enhances transcription and processing and thereby increases snRNA accumulation in pollens (Fig. 8B), relative to the seedling where DSP1β is not expressed (Fig. 8A). Agreeing with this model, we observed increased accumulation of unprocessed presnRNAs in dsps1-1 harboring DSP1β (Fig. 3C) due to increased transcription and reduced efficiency of snRNA processing (low levels of DSP1α). In this model, the function of DSP1β resembles that of the negative elongation factor (NELF) in mammals. NELF interacts with INT, promotes the 3′-end cleavage of presnRNAs, and facilitates Pol II/INT9 recycling from the downstream of 3′-box snRNA loci and snRNA transcription termination (46, 47). Because plants lack NELF, a novel mechanism involving AS of DSP1 is likely evolved to facilitate snRNA transcription termination.Open in a separate windowFig. 8.Model for the function of DSP1α and DSP1β in snRNA biosynthesis. (A) snRNA biogenesis in the tissues containing only DSP1α. “X” indicates the absence of DSP1β in tissues. (B) snRNA biogenesis in the tissues expressing both DSP1α and DSP1β. “?” indicates unknown components. DSP1α functions as a component of the DSP1 complex for snRNA 3′-end maturation. DSP1β facilitates the release of CPSF73-I and Pol II by competitively binding CPSF73-I at the 3′ end of the snRNA loci. Consequently, DSP1β promotes the rapid cycle of the DSP1 complex and snRNA transcription. The coordinate action between DSP1α and DSP1β results in higher accumulation of snRNAs in pollen.Splicing variants are induced by various intrinsic and extrinsic signals to cope with environmental stress or developmental cues (38–44). DSP1β appears to be a tissue or development-specific splicing variant, which facilitates the production of mature snRNAs to meet the requirements of rapid cell division in pollen and embryos. The production of DSP1β is likely controlled by specific splicing factors, whose function or presence is modulated by endogenous developmental signals. DSP1β may require additional machinery for its function (Fig. 8) since its overexpression does not affect snRNA biogenesis in seedlings. Alternatively, DSP1β could function only when the transcription rate of snRNA is high, requiring the rapid recycling of the DSP1 complex and the release of Pol II for preventing transcription read-through.DSP1α and DSP1β may act coordinately in the development of pollen and embryos through, at least, three nonmutually exclusive ways. First, they may contribute to pollen and embryo developments through promoting snRNA biogenesis as snRNAs are essential for splicing (48). Several reports have shown that abnormal snRNA accumulation can cause developmental defects (26, 28, 49). However, the reduction in snRNA accumulation alone cannot fully explain dsp1-1 phenotypes because DSP1β recovers snRNA levels but does not rescue the growth defects. Second, they may contribute to development through preventing 3′-extended transcription from downstream of the snRNA loci. These 3′-read-through transcripts can be translated into functional proteins (13–15). When generated undesirably, these proteins can be toxic to plants. However, inconsistent with this notion, expression of DSP1β removes most of the read-through transcripts but cannot rescue the developmental defects of dsp1-1. Third, DSP1α or DSP1β may affect other biological processes. In mammals, INT also affects transcription termination of mRNAs, biogenesis of some viral-derived miRNAs and enhancer RNAs, and dynein localization at the nuclear envelope (50–55). DSP1 variants may be involved in other RNA metabolism processes.In conclusion, the identification of DSP1β as a regulator of snRNA biogenesis reveals a novel mechanism controlling snRNA accumulation in specific organs through alternative splicing. These results extend the known regulatory mechanisms controlling snRNA accumulation at transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels (16, 29, 46, 56, 57) and add complexity to the regulation of splicing. We also observed similar DSP1 splicing patterns in additional eudicot plants but not in monocots, suggesting that the snRNA regulation mechanism we identified here maybe evolved after the divergence between monocots and eudicots. Future research should identify the process or signals that specifically control the alternative splicing of DSP1 and expand the knowledge on the mechanisms through which it functions. Materials and MethodsPlant Materials. The T-DNA insertion mutant dsp1-1 (SALK_036641) (8) in the Col genetic background was obtained from the Arabidopsis Biological Resources Center (https://abrc.osu.edu).Plasmid Construction. The 2.25 kb promoter region of DSP1 was cloned into pMD18T using XbaI/BamHI restriction sites. The ORFs of DSP1α and DSP1β were, subsequently, inserted downstream of the DSP1 promoter using BamHI/EcoRI restriction sites. The full pDSP1::DSP1α/DSP1β regions were cloned into pGWB433 to generate the pDSP1::DSP1α/DSP1β-GUS vectors. pDSP1:DSP1β was cloned into pGWB17 to generate the pDSP1::DSP1β-MYC vector. The CDS of DSP1β was fused with the HA tag and cloned into pEarleygate103 to generate the 35S::HA-DSP1β-GFP vector. For BiFC assays, pairs of genes were cloned into pEarleyGate201-YC and pEarleyGate202-YN to generate C-terminal YFP and nonfluorescent YFP fusion vectors, respectively. The CDS of DSP1β was cloned into pGEX-6P-1 to generate the recombinant glutathione S-transferase (GST)-DSP1β. Purified GST-DSP1β was used as an antigen to produce the polyclonal anti-DSP1α/β antibody in rabbit. The antibody was generated with the Proteintech Group method, which produces a mix of antibodies recognizing DSP1a/DSP1β, GST, or proteins tagged with GST. To avoid the influence of anti-GST in related experiments, the anti-GSTs were removed with GST-coupling Sepharose beads from the antibody mixture. The primers used for plasmid construction are listed in SI Appendix, Table S2.Histochemical GUS Staining. Seedling or influorescence tissues were collected directly into the GUS staining buffer. Anthers and embryos were dissected from flowers and immature seeds, respectively, under a binocular microscope. After incubation overnight in the staining buffer at 37 °C, the tissues were transferred into 70% ethanol to remove chlorophyll. Three independent WT plants were transformed with pU2::pre-U2m-GUS and crossed into dsp1-1, dsp1-1+DSP1a, dsp1-1+DSP1β, and dsp1-1+DSP1a+DSP1β, parallelly. GUS expression was examined in anthers and embryos.Pollen Observation. Alexander staining was performed as previously described (8). Pollen grain ultrastructures were observed using a TEM according to Pu et al. (2019) (10). Briefly, anthers were fixed, dehydrated, embedded in Epon812, and cut to 80 nm sections with a diamond knife. The sections were collected onto a grid for further staining with uranyl acetate and lead citrate. After washing, the sections were observed with a TEM (JEOL, Japan).U2.3 presnRNA In Vitro Processing Assay. presnRNA-polyG RNA was generated with in vitro transcription by the T7 RNA polymerase, followed by purification in a 5% polyacrylamide gel containing 5 M urea. The RNA was labeled with [32P] at the 5′ end using the T4 polynucleotide kinase. Then, it was incubated for 60 min with 1 μg of a nuclear protein extract obtained from anthers of various genotypes as described before (8, 58). Final RNA products were extracted and resolved on 8% polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis gels containing 5 M urea. The products of the presnRNA processing assay were detected using a PhosphorImager.ChIP Assay. ChIP assays were performed as described before (8). Anti-RPB2 (Abcam) antibodies were used for Pol II IP. The CPSF73-I specific antibody used in the ChiP assay was raised with the C-terminal domain as the antigen. The enrichment of the targets relative to the input was measured by real-time PCR in three biological replicates.Co-IP Assay. For the Co-IP assay, a mixture of Agrobacterium containing different combinations of vectors was infiltrated into the leaves of N. benthamiana. After 2 d, the leaf pieces were collected and used for IP assays as described before (8). The anti-MYC (Abcam) antibody was used for IP. Final IPed proteins were analyzed by Western blot.FRET Assay. The truncated versions of DSP1α (aa 1–504) and CPSF73-I (aa 1–473), containing the domains for protein interaction, were used for the FRET assay in cotransfected N. benthamiana cells. CFP, YFP, and FRET channel signals were obtained by confocal microscopy (Olympus FV3000). The FRET channel images were analyzed using the CellSens Dimension software. Mean normalized FRET data were calculated following NFRET norms (59).NRO Assay. NRO followed the protocol described by Cuello et al. (1999) (13) with modifications. Briefly, 1 μg of synthetic oligonucleotides complementary to different sites of the U2.3 gene (SI Appendix, Table S2) were denatured, transferred to nitrocellulose using a Bio-dot filter (Bio-red), and then fixed with ultraviolet. Then, 20 μg of nuclei extracted from anthers of each genotype were incubated with 7 μL of [α-32P] UTP. After hybridization, nitrocellulose was washed three times in 1× SSE containing 0.1% (wt/vol) sodium dodecyl sulfate. The hybridization signal was detected using a PhosphorImager. Probes complementary to 5S ribosomal RNA and U6 snRNA were used parallelly in the NRO assay as loading controls.
